study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between omega-3 LCPUFAs (including Eicosapentaenoic Acid) in blood and cognitive performance in adolescents.
results_summary: The study found a significant association between higher Omega-3 Index and improved information processing speed (LDST scores) and reduced impulsivity (fewer errors of omission on the D2 test). No significant associations were found for the other cognitive parameters tested.
population_specificity: Typically developing adolescents aged 13-15 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of omega-3 fatty acid supplementation (containing eicosapentaenoic acid) on inflammatory factors, oxidative stress biomarkers, and pregnancy outcomes in women with gestational diabetes.
results_summary: Omega-3 supplementation significantly reduced maternal serum hs-CRP and plasma MDA levels, lowered the incidence of newborn hyperbilirubinemia, and decreased newborn hospitalization rates compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with gestational diabetes (n=56).
effective_dosage: 1000 mg omega-3 fatty acids daily (containing 180 mg eicosapentaenoic acid and 120 mg docosahexaenoic acid).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of EPA on irisin production in cultured human adipocytes and in overweight/obese women following a weight loss program.
results_summary: EPA supplementation (1.3 g/day) did not significantly affect irisin circulating levels in overweight/obese women after weight loss, nor did it show additional effects when combined with α-lipoic acid. The study found no direct link between glucose metabolism and irisin release.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether 2 years of supplementation with marine n-3 PUFAs (EPA and DHA) reduces major cardiovascular events in elderly patients post-acute myocardial infarction.
results_summary: The abstract describes the study design but does not report results, as it appears to be a protocol paper outlining the planned trial.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (70-82 years) who have suffered an acute myocardial infarction.
effective_dosage: 1.8 g EPA + DHA per day (3 capsules of Pikasol®).

study_goal: To evaluate the impact of a hypocaloric diet combined with microencapsulated fish oil supplementation (containing eicosapentaenoic acid) on metabolic parameters in women with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The study found that microencapsulated fish oil supplementation significantly reduced blood glucose, insulin levels, insulin resistance (HOMA), and systolic blood pressure compared to placebo after 90 days.
population_specificity: Adult women with metabolic syndrome (n = 30).
effective_dosage: 3 g/day of microencapsulated fish oil (containing 0.41 g/day of eicosapentaenoic acid and docosahexaenoic acid).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of omega-3 fatty acid supplementation (containing eicosapentaenoic acid) on insulin metabolism and lipid profiles in pregnant women with gestational diabetes.
results_summary: Omega-3 supplementation did not significantly alter serum insulin levels or HOMA-IR within the treatment group but showed a significant difference compared to placebo. It also reduced hs-CRP levels but had no effect on fasting glucose, HOMA-B, QUICKI, or lipid profiles.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with gestational diabetes (n=56).
effective_dosage: 1000 mg omega-3 fatty acids (180 mg EPA + 120 mg DHA) daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of an EPA-enriched oral supplement versus an isocaloric diet on nutritional, clinical, inflammatory parameters, and health-related quality of life in advanced NSCLC patients undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: The EPA-enriched supplement significantly improved energy and protein intake, lean body mass, and reduced fatigue, loss of appetite, and neuropathy compared to the control group, though it did not affect chemotherapy response rate or overall survival.
population_specificity: Advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients receiving paclitaxel and cisplatin/carboplatin chemotherapy.
study_duration: Assessed after the first and second cycles of chemotherapy (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of PUFA supplementation, including eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA), in alleviating ADHD symptoms, particularly inattention and hyperactive-impulsive behaviors.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found modest evidence that PUFA supplementation, including EPA, reduced combined ADHD symptoms, with parent-rated improvements being significant. GLA and its interaction with EPA were associated with decreased inattention symptoms, but no effect was observed for hyperactive-impulsive symptoms.
population_specificity: Individuals with ADHD
study_duration: Varied by study (not specified in abstract)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether preoperative immunonutrition containing eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) could reduce infectious complications and modulate immune responses in patients undergoing pancreatoduodenectomy.
results_summary: The immunonutrition group showed lower infectious complication rates, reduced plasma PGE2 levels, and enhanced T-cell differentiation compared to the control group. EPA levels and EPA/arachidonic acid ratios were significantly higher in the immunonutrition group.
population_specificity: Patients scheduled for pancreatoduodenectomy (n=50, split into immunonutrition and control groups).
effective_dosage: Not specified (part of a combined supplement with arginine and RNA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and potential antiangiogenic and survival benefits of EPA-FFA in patients undergoing liver resection for colorectal cancer liver metastases (CRCLM).
results_summary: EPA-FFA was well tolerated with no excess postoperative complications, increased tumor EPA content by 40%, and showed reduced vascularity in EPA-naïve individuals. While Ki67 proliferation index was unchanged, EPA-FFA-treated patients demonstrated overall survival benefit within 18 months post-surgery.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing liver resection surgery for colorectal cancer liver metastases (CRCLM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of eicosapentaenoic acid as a pharmaceutical therapy for counteracting primary sarcopenia.
results_summary: The abstract mentions eicosapentaenoic acid as one of the pharmaceutical therapies reviewed for sarcopenia but does not provide specific results regarding its efficacy. It suggests that resistance training combined with amino acid supplementation is more effective than pharmaceutical therapies for age-related muscle wasting.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals with primary sarcopenia (age-related muscle loss).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how dietary EPA intake affects skin levels of AA, EPA, and their eicosanoids, both under basal conditions and after UVR challenge.
results_summary: EPA supplementation increased skin EPA levels, reduced AA:EPA ratios, and shifted eicosanoid production toward less pro-inflammatory species, particularly reducing PGE2 and increasing PGE3 and 12-HEPE post-UVR exposure.
population_specificity: 79 females

study_goal: To evaluate the body weight-lowering effects of EPA supplementation, alone or combined with α-lipoic acid, in healthy overweight/obese women on a hypocaloric diet.
results_summary: EPA supplementation did not significantly enhance weight loss compared to control but attenuated the decrease in leptin levels during weight loss. Combined EPA and α-lipoic acid showed no additional weight loss benefit over α-lipoic acid alone.
population_specificity: Healthy overweight/obese women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) on glycemic indices in overweight patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: EPA supplementation significantly reduced fasting plasma glucose, HbA1c, serum insulin levels, and insulin resistance (HOMA-IR) compared to placebo. The results suggest EPA improves insulin sensitivity and glycemic control in T2DM patients.
population_specificity: Overweight patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (n=67).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of different treatment modalities, including an EPA-enriched nutritional supplement, in managing cancer cachexia.
results_summary: The study found that EPA supplementation, when combined with meloxicam or MA plus meloxicam, improved body weight, lean body mass, and other secondary parameters, but no significant differences were observed between treatment groups.
population_specificity: Cachectic cancer patients (n=62)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether n-3 fatty acid supplementation (including eicosapentaenoic acid) could increase transthyretin (TTR) levels in patients with Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: The study found that n-3 fatty acid supplementation (1.7 g DHA and 0.6 g EPA) increased plasma-TTR levels in AD patients after 6 months, with further increases observed after 12 months of supplementation. No changes were detected in cerebrospinal fluid TTR levels.
population_specificity: Outpatients with Alzheimer's disease (mean age 75 years, mixed gender).
effective_dosage: 1.7 g DHA and 0.6 g EPA daily.
study_duration: 6 months (initial phase), followed by an additional 6 months for all participants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether n-3 PUFA supplementation (including EPA) enhances striatal VMAT2 availability and improves dopamine-dependent cognitive functions like working memory in humans.
results_summary: The study found no significant change in VMAT2 availability post-supplementation, but working memory performance improved, correlating with higher DHA levels. The cognitive benefits of n-3 PUFA were not mediated by VMAT2 regulation.
population_specificity: Healthy young adults
effective_dosage: 2 g/day (containing EPA 930 mg/d and DHA 750 mg/d)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether milled chia seed supplementation could increase plasma EPA levels and influence inflammation or disease risk factors in overweight, postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found that milled chia seed supplementation increased plasma EPA by 39% but had no significant effect on inflammation or disease risk factors compared to whole chia seed or placebo.
population_specificity: Overweight (BMI ≥25 kg/m²), nondiseased, nonsmoking, postmenopausal women aged 49-75 years.
effective_dosage: 25 g/day of milled or whole chia seed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the clinical effects of omega-3 fatty acid supplementation (specifically EPA and DHA) on behavior and locomotion in cats with naturally occurring osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Cats supplemented with fish oil (containing EPA and DHA) showed improved activity levels, reduced stiffness during gait, increased interaction with owners, and higher jumps compared to those on corn oil. Some results were statistically significant (p=0.03), while others showed trends (p=0.07).
population_specificity: 16 cats with radiologically documented, naturally occurring osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: 1.53 g EPA and 0.31 g DHA per 1000 kcal ME (equivalent to the complete diet).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of omega-3 fatty acids, including eicosapentaenoic acid, on serum adiponectin levels and metabolic risk factors in PCOS patients.
results_summary: Omega-3 fatty acids significantly increased adiponectin levels, improved insulin resistance, and positively altered lipid profiles, including reductions in glucose, insulin, total cholesterol, and LDL cholesterol, while increasing HDL cholesterol. No significant changes were observed in hs-CRP levels.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese PCOS patients aged 20-35 years.
effective_dosage: 4 capsules daily (each containing 180 mg eicosapentaenoic acid and 120 mg docosahexaenoic acid).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if genetic polymorphisms in the MGLL gene influence LDL cholesterol levels and particle size variability in response to n-3 PUFA (including eicosapentaenoic acid) supplementation.
results_summary: The study found that 55% of subjects increased LDL-C levels after n-3 PUFA supplementation, and specific MGLL gene SNPs showed gene-diet interaction effects on LDL-C concentrations and particle size.
population_specificity: 210 subjects (specific demographics not detailed).
effective_dosage: 5 g/d of fish oil (1.9-2.2 g eicosapentaenoic acid and 1.1 g docosahexaenoic acid).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of ω-3 PUFA (including eicosapentaenoic acid) supplementation on body composition, insulin resistance, and lipemia in women with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that a lower dose (1.5 g/d) of ω-3 PUFA led to greater reductions in body mass and waist circumference, improved lipid metabolism, and more frequent reductions in glycemic and total cholesterol levels compared to a higher dose (2.5 g/d). However, the higher dose reduced insulin sensitivity.
population_specificity: 41 women (60.64 ± 7.82 years) with type 2 diabetes and high blood pressure.
effective_dosage: 2.5 g/d fish oil (GA group) and 1.5 g/d fish oil (GB group), with capsules containing 21.9% eicosapentaenoic acid and 14.1% docosapentaenoic acid.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether perioperative nutrition enriched with eicosapentaenoic acid could prevent body weight loss after total gastrectomy for gastric cancer.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results, as it describes a planned Phase III trial rather than reporting outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing total gastrectomy for gastric cancer.
effective_dosage: Not specified (standard diet with eicosapentaenoic acid-enriched supplementation for 7 days before and 21 days after surgery).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) supplementation on seizure frequency and severity in individuals with refractory focal seizures.
results_summary: Six out of ten participants experienced a reduction in seizure frequency (12-59% reduction), and one had reduced seizure severity, though the mean reduction was modest (16%) and not statistically significant (p=0.26). The study suggests a possible weak effect of EPA on seizures but highlights the need for larger, controlled trials.
population_specificity: Ten individuals (five males) with refractory focal seizures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether oral eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) supplementation could prevent ribavirin-induced hemolytic anemia in pediatric and young adult patients undergoing hepatitis C therapy.
results_summary: EPA supplementation significantly reduced hemoglobin level declines at 8 and 16 weeks compared to the control group, without affecting plasma ribavirin concentrations. One control group patient required a ribavirin dose reduction, while no such cases occurred in the EPA group.
population_specificity: Pediatric and young adult patients (ages 3–21 years) with chronic hepatitis C receiving pegylated interferon α-2b and ribavirin therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of eicosapentaenoic acid supplementation on lean body mass in cancer cachexia and identify limitations in current studies to improve future clinical trials.
results_summary: Initial studies showed promising improvements in lean body mass, appetite, and quality of life, but larger phase III trials reported minimal benefits. Recent studies with varied designs may help explain divergent results.
population_specificity: Advanced cancer patients with cachexia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the acute effects of EPA- or DHA-rich oil supplementation on platelet aggregation, microparticle levels, and activity in healthy individuals, with a focus on gender-specific responses.
results_summary: EPA and DHA reduced platelet aggregation at 24 hours post-supplementation, but only EPA reduced microparticle activity. Males showed significant reductions in both platelet aggregation and microparticle activity with EPA, while females showed reduced platelet aggregation with DHA but no change in microparticle activity.
population_specificity: Healthy males and females (n=30)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the acceptability and feasibility of a multi-targeted approach combining Eicosapentaenoic Acid (EPA) with celecoxib, resistance training, and essential amino acids in lung cancer patients with cachexia.
results_summary: The study found some benefit from the combination of EPA and celecoxib in a small cohort, but the primary focus was on the acceptability of the multi-targeted approach rather than efficacy outcomes. The experimental group included resistance training and amino acid supplementation, but detailed results on EPA's specific effects were not provided.
population_specificity: Non-small cell lung cancer patients experiencing cancer cachexia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the efficacy of omega-3 fatty acid supplementation, particularly eicosapentaenoic acid, in improving ADHD symptoms in children.
results_summary: Omega-3 fatty acid supplementation showed a small but significant effect in improving ADHD symptoms, with higher doses of eicosapentaenoic acid correlating with greater efficacy. The effect was modest compared to traditional pharmacotherapies but had a benign side-effect profile.
population_specificity: Children with ADHD symptomatology
effective_dosage: Not specified (dose of eicosapentaenoic acid was correlated with efficacy but exact amounts not provided)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether E-EPA supplementation increases serum BDNF levels and whether changes in BDNF levels correlate with changes in depression severity in diabetes patients with major depression.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of E-EPA on BDNF levels and no significant association between changes in BDNF levels and depression severity.
population_specificity: Diabetes patients with major depression already using antidepressants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether n-3 supplementation, specifically eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA), reduces proinflammatory cytokine production and depressive or anxiety symptoms in healthy young adults.
results_summary: The study found that n-3 supplementation led to a 14% decrease in LPS-stimulated IL-6 production and a 20% reduction in anxiety symptoms, but no significant change in depressive symptoms. Secondary analyses showed that lower n-6:n-3 ratios correlated with reduced anxiety and inflammation markers.
population_specificity: 68 healthy medical students
effective_dosage: 2.5 g/day (2085 mg EPA and 348 mg DHA)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of dietary components, including eicosapentaenoic acid, on gene expression and plasma concentration of adiponectin.
results_summary: The study found that diets rich in polyunsaturated fatty acids and supplementation with omega-3 and eicosapentaenoic acid increased adiponectin gene expression and plasma levels in animal models. In humans, healthy and Mediterranean diets were positively associated with adiponectin levels, though mechanisms remain unclear.
population_specificity: Animal models and human subjects (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of n-3 PUFA supplementation (specifically fish oil containing eicosapentaenoic acid) on erythrocyte phospholipid and breast milk lipid composition in pregnant women.
results_summary: The FO group showed higher docosahexaenoic acid and eicosapentaenoic acid levels in erythrocyte phospholipids and a lower n-6/n-3 PUFA ratio in breast milk lipids compared to the control group. No significant changes were observed in plasma anti-oxLDL autoantibodies or thiobarbituric acid-reactive substance concentrations between groups.
population_specificity: Pregnant Brazilian women in the 30th week of gestation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) supplementation could prevent weight loss and deterioration of body composition in patients with nonsmall cell lung cancer undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: Patients receiving EPA maintained their weight and muscle mass, while the standard care group experienced significant weight and muscle loss. Greater increases in plasma EPA concentration correlated with greater muscle gains.
population_specificity: Newly referred patients with nonsmall cell lung cancer initiating first-line chemotherapy.
study_duration: From initiation to completion of first-line chemotherapy (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the association between omega-3 PUFA supplementation (including Eicosapentaenoic Acid) during the perinatal period and the risk of maternal perinatal depression.
results_summary: The study found mixed results, with six studies showing no association, two showing mixed results, and two reporting a positive association between omega-3 PUFAs and reduced incidence of maternal perinatal depression. Higher doses (close to 2 g DHA + EPA) and earlier supplementation in pregnancy were more likely to show positive effects.
population_specificity: Pregnant and postpartum women (perinatal period).
effective_dosage: Close to 2 g DHA + EPA (specific frequency not mentioned).
study_duration: Duration varied by study (not specified in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary supplementation with omega-3 fatty acids from Clupeonella grimmi could relieve symptoms of dysmenorrhoea in young women.
results_summary: The study found that fish oil supplementation significantly reduced dysmenorrhoea symptoms (visual analogue scale score 20.9 vs. 61.8 for placebo, P=0.001), decreased low back and abdominal pain (P<0.05), and reduced the need for ibuprofen rescue doses.
population_specificity: 36 girls aged 18-22 years with dysmenorrhoea.
effective_dosage: 15 mL fish oil daily (550 mg eicosapentaenoic acid, 205 mg docosahexaenoic acid).

study_goal: To examine interactions between fish oil (containing eicosapentaenoic acid) and paracetamol for inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.
results_summary: Paracetamol suppressed COX-1 and COX-2 activity more effectively in the High EPA group, with the combination of fish oil and paracetamol suppressing PGE(2) synthesis comparably to maximum therapeutic NSAID doses.
population_specificity: Patients with early rheumatoid arthritis treated with a standardized DMARD regimen.
effective_dosage: Anti-inflammatory dose of fish oil (specific amount not stated); blood EPA levels >3.5% defined High EPA group.
interactions: Enhanced suppression of PGE(2) synthesis when combined with paracetamol.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Eicosapentaenoic Acid (EPA) on renal function and clinical parameters in patients with IgA nephropathy.
results_summary: EPA administration (1.8 g/day for 12 months) showed a non-significant trend toward improved serum creatinine and urinary protein levels, with a significant improvement in estimated creatinine clearance (eCCr). No adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: Biopsy-confirmed IgA nephropathy patients (aged 31 ± 3 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to measure the efficacy of eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) in improving ADHD symptoms in children, focusing on specific subgroups.
results_summary: EPA improved inattention/cognitive subscale scores in children with ADHD, particularly in oppositional and less hyperactive/impulsive subgroups. Baseline fatty acid ratios (AA/EPA, AA/DHA) were predictive of treatment response, with higher EPA and lower omega-6 concentrations linked to clinical improvement.
population_specificity: Children aged 7-12 years with ADHD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a supplement containing eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) improves depressive symptoms and health-related quality of life in depressed elderly women.
results_summary: The study found that supplementation with n-3 LCPUFA significantly reduced depressive symptoms and improved both physical and mental health-related quality of life in elderly depressed women, as measured by the GDS and SF-36 scales. Compliance was confirmed by increased EPA and DHA levels in erythrocyte membranes.
population_specificity: Depressed elderly women (aged 66-95 years) residing in a nursing home in Pavia, Italy.
effective_dosage: 2.5 g/d of n-3 LCPUFA (1.67 g EPA and 0.83 g DHA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether intravenous bolus injection of a novel MCT:FO emulsion could rapidly enrich leukocyte and platelet phospholipids with n-3 PUFAs, specifically eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA).
results_summary: The study found that intravenous MCT:FO injection led to faster plasma elimination and a significant increase in n-3 PUFAs, particularly EPA, in leukocyte and platelet phospholipids within 60 minutes and up to 24 hours post-injection, with no adverse effects on clinical or biological safety markers.
population_specificity: Twelve healthy male subjects.
effective_dosage: 50 mL of MCT:FO emulsion (20 g triacylglycerols/100 mL, 80% MCTs and 20% fish oil, with 0.4 g alpha-tocopherol/100 mL).
study_duration: Single bolus injection over 5 minutes, with follow-up assessments up to 24 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the blood lipid-lowering effects of EPA in hypertriglyceridemic subjects with different FABP2 genotypes (Ala54 vs. Thr54).
results_summary: EPA supplementation significantly reduced triacylglycerol, very low-density lipoprotein, and apolipoprotein CIII while increasing high-density lipoprotein cholesterol, with more pronounced effects in Thr54 carriers. No significant changes were observed in total cholesterol, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, or apolipoprotein B.
population_specificity: Hypertriglyceridemic subjects (triacylglycerol >200mg/dL) with FABP2 Ala54 or Thr54 genotypes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antiviral efficacy of standardized black elderberry fruit extract (EC 3.2) and quinine against Influenza A virus (IAV) and SARS-CoV-2 in vitro, including potential synergistic effects.
results_summary: The study found that both EC 3.2 and quinine individually inhibited IAV replication in a dose-dependent manner, with IC50 values of approximately 1:400 for EC 3.2 and 250 nM for quinine. The combinational treatment showed strong synergistic antiviral effects against both IAV and SARS-CoV-2 without affecting cell viability.
population_specificity: In vitro study using Madin-Darby Canine Kidney II (MDCKII) cells for IAV and human Calu-3 lung epithelial cells for SARS-CoV-2.
effective_dosage: Varying concentrations of EC 3.2 and quinine; IC50 values provided.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether elderberry consumption affects serum thyroid biomarkers in mice and humans, potentially explaining its metabolic benefits.
results_summary: Short-term elderberry juice consumption in humans significantly increased T4 and TSH levels, suggesting enhanced metabolic rate, while in rodents, EBJ powder led to a non-significant reduction in T4. No change in thyroglobulin was observed in humans.
population_specificity: 18 humans (meal-tolerance test) and 33 male mice (high-fat diet).
study_duration: 7 days for humans, 13 weeks for mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential therapeutic applications of elderberry hydrolate in palliative care, particularly for addressing dermatological issues like irritation, dryness, pruritus, and inflammation.
results_summary: The study found that elderberry hydrolate contains bioactive compounds with anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, antimicrobial, and skin-healing properties, making it promising for palliative care. However, barriers like cost, accessibility, and regulatory challenges hinder widespread implementation.
population_specificity: Palliative care patients with compromised skin health due to illness or treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining Elderberry with Saffron and Melilotus could enhance protective effects against oxidative damage in retinal pigment epithelial cells compared to Saffron alone.
results_summary: The combination of Saffron, Elderberry, and Melilotus was more effective than Saffron alone in preventing caspase-1 activation and showed additive benefits in reducing oxidative stress and improving cell viability. The mix also activated the NRF2 pathway, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits for retinal degenerative diseases.
population_specificity: ARPE-19 retinal pigment epithelial cells (in vitro study)
study_duration: Pretreatment duration not specified; H2O2 exposure lasted 3 hours

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an elderberry (EB) diet could mitigate reproductive toxicity induced by methamphetamine (METH) exposure in male rats.
results_summary: The EB diet improved sperm parameters, increased serum testosterone levels, and reduced TNF-α and caspase-3 expression in METH-exposed rats compared to the METH-only group.
population_specificity: Adult male rats
effective_dosage: Not specified (EB diet composition not detailed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if anthocyanin-dense elderberry juice (EBJ) improves glucoregulation and substrate oxidation, and whether these effects are mediated by gut microbiota.
results_summary: EBJ significantly altered gut microbiota composition, reduced blood glucose post-meal tolerance testing, and increased fat oxidation during testing and moderate physical activity. These findings suggest EBJ has beneficial effects on metabolic health and obesity-related outcomes.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese adults (BMI > 25 kg/m²) without chronic illnesses.
effective_dosage: Twice-daily elderberry juice (specific amount not stated).
study_duration: Two 1-week periods separated by a washout period (total intervention: 2 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether elderberry extract and its derived monosaccharide-amino acid (FL) could improve testosterone biosynthesis and reduce oxidative stress in mitochondrial dysfunction TM3 cells.
results_summary: Elderberry extract and FL significantly reduced ROS levels, improved testosterone secretion, and increased expression of steroidogenesis-related enzymes, while inhibiting the conversion of testosterone to estradiol by reducing CYP19A1 expression.
population_specificity: Mouse Leydig (TM3) cells with induced mitochondrial dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of sequential thermal treatment with ultrasound (US) or high hydrostatic pressure (HHP) on pea protein-psyllium hydrogels as carriers for elderberry extract, focusing on stability, entrapment efficiency, and bioactive preservation.
results_summary: Thermal and HHP-combined induction improved hydrogel strength, uniformity, and elderberry extract entrapment efficiency (33% for P10), while preserving polyphenol content, antioxidant activity, and reducing power. Thermal and US combined induction resulted in color changes and reduced entrapment efficiency.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)
study_duration: Treatment durations included extended secondary treatment (10 min for HHP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the biological activity of elderberry leaves, focusing on antioxidant potential, inhibition of tyrosinase and hyaluronidase enzymes, and phytochemical composition.
results_summary: Elderberry leaf extracts demonstrated antioxidant effects, with the "Sampo" variety showing high phenolic content and anti-inflammatory activity (41.28% hyaluronidase inhibition). "Sampo" and "Golden hybrid" extracts also facilitated wound healing in scratch tests.
population_specificity: Elderberry leaves from 12 varieties in two growth stages (younger and older leaves).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential interaction between elderberry supplements and pazopanib, a cytotoxic medication, in a cancer patient.
results_summary: The study reported a case of severe liver injury and gastrointestinal side effects in a patient taking elderberry supplements concurrently with pazopanib. Symptoms resolved after discontinuing elderberry, suggesting a possible interaction.
population_specificity: Middle-aged woman with localized intermediate-grade sarcoma.
study_duration: Several years (elderberry use), 4 weeks (pazopanib with elderberry).
interactions: Potential interaction with pazopanib via CYP3A4 inhibition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an elderberry diet could improve motor function and reduce neurodegeneration in a rat model of cerebellar ataxia induced by 3-acetylpyridine.
results_summary: Elderberry diet improved motor coordination, locomotor activity, and neuromuscular function, prevented Purkinje neuron degeneration, reduced apoptosis, and modulated inflammatory and antioxidant gene expression in the cerebellum of ataxic rats.
population_specificity: 3-acetylpyridine-induced cerebellar ataxia rat model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether elderberry fruit and leaf extracts could enhance recovery in the stasis zone of burn wounds by reducing oxidative stress and promoting healing.
results_summary: The study found that elderberry leaf extracts showed superior healing effects compared to fruit extracts, with significant improvements in collagenization, VEGF immunoreactivity, and reduced MDA levels. However, no significant differences were observed between treatment groups in terms of inflammatory cell infiltration or re-epithelialization.
population_specificity: 56 healthy rats subjected to a comb burn model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of 100% elderberry juice on indirect calorimetry measures and insulin sensitivity/glucose tolerance in overweight and obese adults.
results_summary: The study found that elderberry juice significantly increased carbohydrate oxidation but decreased fat oxidation during a meal tolerance test, with no effect on energy expenditure or insulin/glucose response.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese adults (18 females, 4 males initially; 9 analyzed).
effective_dosage: Twice-daily consumption of elderberry juice (exact volume not specified).
study_duration: 1-week intervention periods separated by a 3-week washout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of elderberry (Sambucus nigra) for preventing and treating viral diseases, particularly COVID-19, by reviewing existing literature.
results_summary: Elderberry exhibits antiviral properties by modulating inflammatory cytokines, making it potentially useful for viral disease prevention and early treatment. However, concerns about immune overstimulation and cytokine storm risk remain unresolved due to insufficient evidence.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the immunomodulatory potential of Sambucus ebulus (SE) fruit infusion intake in healthy humans, focusing on its effects on immune response mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found a significant decrease in pro-inflammatory markers (IL-6, TNFα, IL-8, C3, C4) and total protein levels, indicating immune-modulatory activity. Effects varied by gender, with notable reductions in IL-6 in men and other markers in women.
population_specificity: Healthy human volunteers (n=53).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the prebiotic properties of a standardized elderberry extract and its effects on the intestinal microbiome.
results_summary: The elderberry extract was well tolerated and induced individualized microbiome shifts, including increased Akkermansia spp. abundance in some participants even after supplementation ended. Microbiome diversity and species abundance changed significantly during and after the intervention.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential effect of elderberry on spermatogenesis in azoospermic mice induced by busulfan.
results_summary: The study found that elderberry supplementation improved spermatogenesis in busulfan-induced azoospermic mice, as evidenced by sperm parameter analysis, histopathological evaluation, and oxidative stress markers. The elderberry diet was suggested as a complementary treatment for testicular damage following chemotherapy.
population_specificity: Adult male mice with busulfan-induced azoospermia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if an elderberry diet could improve spermatogenesis and related parameters in mice subjected to scrotal hyperthermia.
results_summary: The elderberry diet significantly improved sperm parameters, stereological parameters (e.g., spermatogonia, primary spermatocyte, round spermatid, Leydig cells), and serum testosterone levels while reducing TNF-α and caspase-3 expression compared to hyperthermia-induced mice.
population_specificity: Male mice subjected to scrotal hyperthermia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether SC-Nanophytosomes, combining elderberry anthocyanin-enriched extract with algae membrane polar lipids, could effectively target mitochondria and improve mitochondrial function in neurodegenerative disease models.
results_summary: SC-Nanophytosomes improved mitochondrial respiratory chain complexes I and II, preserved mitochondrial membrane potential, and protected SH-SY5Y cells against rotenone- and glutamate-induced toxicity. The formulation was internalized via caveola-mediated endocytosis and reached mitochondria, suggesting potential for mitochondria-targeted therapy.
population_specificity: In vitro study using SH-SY5Y neuroblastoma cells.
effective_dosage: 0.5 mg/L of elderberry anthocyanin-enriched extract combined with 600 µM algae membrane polar lipids.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the benefits and harms of elderberry for preventing and treating viral respiratory infections, as well as assess its potential to overstimulate the immune system.
results_summary: Elderberry may reduce the duration and severity of colds and influenza, but evidence is uncertain. No evidence links elderberry to clinical inflammatory outcomes, and it appears safe without overstimulating the immune system.
population_specificity: Individuals with or at risk of viral respiratory infections.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of adjunctive agents, including ethyl eicosapentaenoic acid (E-EPA), in clozapine-resistant schizophrenic patients.
results_summary: The study found evidence supporting the use of E-EPA as an adjunct to clozapine for treatment-resistant schizophrenia, though further validation is needed. The meta-analysis did not support other adjunctive treatments like risperidone or lamotrigine.
population_specificity: Schizophrenic or schizoaffective patients resistant to clozapine treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Elderberry (EB) could ameliorate inflammatory and oxidative responses in a rat model of Huntington's disease (HD) induced by 3-nitropropionic acid (3-NP).
results_summary: EB diet significantly improved motor failure and muscle incoordination in 3-NP injected rats, reduced caspase-3 and TNF-α levels, and enhanced striatal antioxidative capacity by lowering ROS and increasing GSH.
population_specificity: Rats injected with 3-NP to model Huntington's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the synthesis of gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) using Elderberry extract and assess their anti-cancer properties on prostate (PC-3) and pancreatic (Panc-1) cancer cells.
results_summary: Elderberry extract alone did not show toxicity to the tested cancer cells, while Elderberry-derived AuNPs demonstrated potential anti-cancer activity against both prostate and pancreatic cancer cells. Further studies are needed to understand the mechanism and specificity of these effects.
population_specificity: Prostate (PC-3) and pancreatic (Panc-1) cancer cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether elderberry fruit extract could mitigate oxidative stress, inflammation, and metabolic dysfunction in hypertrophied adipocytes and macrophages, as well as its potential effects on digestive enzymes.
results_summary: The study found that elderberry extract reduced reactive oxygen species, modulated adipokine expression (down-regulating leptin and up-regulating adiponectin), improved glucose uptake in adipocytes, and suppressed inflammatory markers in macrophages. It also inhibited digestive enzymes, suggesting potential benefits for obesity and metabolic disorders.
population_specificity: In vitro models (3T3-L1 adipocytes and RAW 264.7 macrophages)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether elderberry extract decreases the duration and severity of influenza.
results_summary: The study found no evidence that elderberry benefits the duration or severity of influenza, with no significant difference between the elderberry and placebo groups. Post hoc analysis suggested elderberry taken alone might worsen outcomes compared to placebo alone.
population_specificity: Patients over age four with <48 hours of at least two moderate-severity influenza symptoms and a positive PCR influenza test.
effective_dosage: 15 ml (5.7 g) twice daily for ages 5-12; 15 ml four times daily for ages >12.
interactions: Patients were permitted to also receive oseltamivir.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different genotypes of elderberry respond to varying nitrogen (N) fertilizer treatments at the proteome level.
results_summary: The study identified 165 proteins with significant abundance changes under different N-treatments, with Bob Gordon showing distinct responses. Among these, 23 proteins involved in photosynthesis, protein metabolism, and redox homeostasis remained unaffected by N-treatment or genotype.
population_specificity: Three genotypes of elderberry plants (Adams II, Bob Gordon, Wyldewood).
effective_dosage: Not specified (N-fertilizer treatment levels not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the thermal degradation kinetics and phytochemical characterization of elderberry extract, focusing on the impact of heat treatment on bioactive compounds.
results_summary: Heating elderberry extract at 100-150°C for up to 90 minutes reduced fluorescence intensity and caused molecular changes in anthocyanins, affecting antioxidant activity. Degradation rate constants decreased with higher temperatures, and activation energies for fluorescence intensity, anthocyanins, and antioxidant activity were quantified.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)
study_duration: Heating durations ranged from up to 90 minutes to 120 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the sensitivity of elderberry lectins to proteolysis and the impact of heat treatment on their allergenicity and antioxidant properties.
results_summary: The study found that elderberry lectins are resistant to proteolysis but become sensitive to hydrolytic enzymes after brief heat treatment (5-10 min in boiling water). Heat treatment did not significantly affect antioxidant and free-radical scavenging activities (less than 10% reduction for up to 20 min).
population_specificity: In vitro simulated gastric and duodenal fluids (no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the effects of elderberry phenolic extracts, anthocyanins, and procyanidins on glucose and fatty acid uptake in skeletal muscle cells, antioxidant activity, and inhibition of carbohydrate-hydrolyzing enzymes.
results_summary: Elderberry extracts enhanced glucose and oleic acid uptake in human skeletal muscle cells, exhibited strong antioxidant effects, and were effective inhibitors of α-amylase and α-glucosidase, outperforming acarbose. The most active compounds were cyanidin-3-glucoside, cyanidin-3-sambubioside, and phloroglucinol aldehyde.
population_specificity: Human skeletal muscle cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether elderberry supplementation could mitigate brain injury and neuroinflammatory responses following cerebral ischemia/reperfusion in mice.
results_summary: Elderberry supplementation reduced sensorimotor impairment, decreased neuronal cell death, and significantly lowered microglial activation and oxidative stress markers in mice subjected to cerebral ischemia/reperfusion.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J male mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of Fenton's oxidation for treating elderberry juice wastewater to meet legal discharge thresholds.
results_summary: Fenton's oxidation achieved at least 70% COD reduction, complete phenolic content degradation, and produced an effluent suitable for direct discharge, with a reactant cost of 4.38 € m(-3).
population_specificity: Not applicable (wastewater treatment study).
effective_dosage: [Fe(2+)] = 20 mmol L(-1), [H2O2] = 100 mmol L(-1), pH = 3, 4 h oxidation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the materials used in a sixth-century illuminated manuscript, including identifying the use of elderberry lake as a coloring agent.
results_summary: The study identified elderberry lake as a coloring material in the manuscript, characterized using Raman spectroscopy, marking the first experimental evidence of its use in a sixth-century illuminated manuscript.
population_specificity: Sixth-century illuminated manuscript (Codex Rossanensis)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the anthocyanin content in elderberry products to assess their potential as functional food for metabolic syndrome or influenza.
results_summary: The study found that three elderberry and six chokeberry products were analyzed for anthocyanin content, with three deemed inappropriate for clinical use. The lowest effective liquid doses were 11 mL for elderberry concentrate and 100 mL for chokeberry mother juice.
population_specificity: Patients with metabolic syndrome or influenza.
effective_dosage: 110 mg per day for metabolic syndrome, 3.5 g per day for influenza.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory effects of silver nanoparticles synthesized using European black elderberry fruit extracts.
results_summary: The study demonstrated anti-inflammatory effects of elderberry-derived silver nanoparticles in vitro (reduced cytokine production in UVB-exposed HaCaT cells), in vivo (reduced edema and cytokines in acute inflammation models), and in humans (potential for treating psoriasis lesions).
population_specificity: HaCaT cells (in vitro), acute inflammation model (in vivo), and humans with psoriasis lesions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of elderberry in pregnancy and its effectiveness against upper respiratory tract infections.
results_summary: The study found no human or animal safety data for elderberry in pregnancy. All three clinical trials concluded elderberry is effective against influenza, but the sample size was small (77 persons).
population_specificity: Pregnant women and general population (for efficacy trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and confirm the pathogen causing shriveled elderberry fruits and assess its pathogenicity on black elderberry.
results_summary: The study identified Colletotrichum acutatum as the pathogen causing shriveled elderberry fruits and confirmed its pathogenicity through inoculation tests. No symptoms were observed in control treatments.
population_specificity: Elderberry plants in an experimental plot and research center in Switzerland.
study_duration: Inoculation occurred in May 2010, with fruit harvest and incubation in July 2010.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the habitat characteristics of blue elderberry in altered riparian systems and examine associated plant species composition to inform restoration efforts for the Valley elderberry longhorn beetle.
results_summary: The study found that elderberry was most common on higher, older floodplain surfaces and in black walnut-dominated woodlands, but saplings and small shrubs were rare, indicating poor recruitment. Invasive species were associated with elderberry, potentially outcompeting seedlings for resources.
population_specificity: Riparian forest patches along the Sacramento River and four adjacent rivers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the safety and efficacy of chronic elderberry anthocyanin consumption on cardiovascular disease biomarkers and liver/kidney function in healthy postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found that 500 mg/day of elderberry extract for 12 weeks was safe, with no significant changes in CVD biomarkers or liver/kidney function, but also ineffective in altering CVD risk markers. Postprandial anthocyanin metabolism increased, but no plasma accumulation was observed.
population_specificity: Healthy postmenopausal women (n=52, BMI 24.7 ± 3.6 kg/m², age 58.2 ± 5.6 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize thaumatin-like proteins (TLPs) in elderberry fruits and leaves, examining their developmental regulation and induction under different treatments.
results_summary: The study found that ripening elderberries accumulated a fruit-specific TLP without antifungal or beta-glucanase activity, while leaves constitutively expressed a similar TLP. Jasmonate methyl ester induced additional TLPs in leaves but not berries, whereas ethephon and garlic extract induced TLP expression in unripe berries.
population_specificity: Elderberry fruits and leaves (no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of a standardized elderberry extract (Sambucol) in inhibiting influenza virus replication and improving symptoms during an influenza B outbreak.
results_summary: The elderberry extract significantly reduced hemagglutination and inhibited replication of multiple influenza strains in vitro. In the clinical study, 93.3% of the treated group showed symptom improvement within 2 days, and nearly 90% achieved complete cure within 2-3 days, compared to 6 days in the placebo group.
population_specificity: Individuals living in an agricultural community (kibbutz) during an influenza B outbreak.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the binding properties of a modified Sambucus sieboldiana bark lectin (MSSA) to cell surface glycoconjugates containing NeuAc alpha 2-6Gal/GalNAc sequences.
results_summary: MSSA retained binding ability to fetuin but lost agglutination properties. It effectively stained human histocytic lymphoma U937 cells without agglutination, and this staining was inhibited by Neu5Ac alpha 2-6lactose, suggesting MSSA's utility for detecting specific glycoconjugates.
population_specificity: Human histocytic lymphoma U937 cells (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: Sub-agglutinating concentration (0.3 microgram/ml) for native FITC-SSA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy and safety of oral elderberry syrup for treating influenza A and B infections.
results_summary: Elderberry syrup relieved symptoms on average 4 days earlier and significantly reduced the need for rescue medication compared to placebo. The study concluded that elderberry extract is an efficient, safe, and cost-effective treatment for influenza.
population_specificity: 60 patients aged 18-54 years with influenza-like symptoms for 48 hours or less.
effective_dosage: 15 ml four times a day for 5 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the carbohydrate binding properties of a new plant lectin (SNA) isolated from elderberry bark, focusing on its interaction with sialylated glycoproteins.
results_summary: The study found that SNA preferentially binds to glycoproteins with terminal Neu5Ac(α2-6)Gal sequences, showing high inhibitory potency, while Neu5Ac(α2-3)Gal linkages were less effective. The glyceryl side chain of Neu5Ac was identified as a critical determinant for binding, and the lectin exhibited two equivalent carbohydrate binding sites.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review regulatory requirements and analytical approaches for verifying ingredient claims in botanical products, including elderberry, to ensure safety and label compliance.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on elderberry's effects but highlights concerns about adulteration and inaccurate labeling in botanical products marketed for immune health.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the effects of elderberry supplementation on upper respiratory symptoms and evaluate moderators like vaccination status and underlying pathology.
results_summary: Elderberry supplementation substantially reduced upper respiratory symptoms, with a large mean effect size, suggesting it as an alternative to antibiotics and prescription drugs for viral infections.
population_specificity: 180 participants with upper respiratory symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential of elderberry extract (EE) for its antiviral and vascular protective properties, particularly in relation to COVID-19 and endothelial dysfunction.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that elderberry, rich in anthocyanins like cyanidin-3-glucoside (C3G), may have vascular protective and antiviral properties, but further in vitro and in vivo research is needed to confirm its mechanisms and efficacy against SARS-CoV-2.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of potential effects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential health benefits of fruit-derived polyphenols, including elderberry, in enhancing exercise performance and vascular function.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that fruit-derived polyphenols, including elderberry, may have anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and vascular benefits, but specific results for elderberry are not provided.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a standardized elderberry extract could improve physical (especially respiratory) and mental health in air travelers.
results_summary: The study found that elderberry significantly reduced the duration and severity of cold episodes in air travelers compared to placebo, though the difference in the number of cold episodes was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: 312 economy class passengers traveling from Australia to an overseas destination.
study_duration: Intervention duration not explicitly stated, but outcomes were measured at baseline, pre-travel, and 4 days post-travel.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and quantify the phenolic metabolites of anthocyanins in humans following elderberry consumption.
results_summary: The study identified 28 anthocyanin metabolites in urine and 21 in plasma, with phenolic metabolites reaching much higher concentrations than parent anthocyanins. Chronic exposure did not alter metabolite profiles or quantities compared to acute exposure.
population_specificity: Healthy post-menopausal women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of transcutaneous electric nerve stimulation (TENS) and photobiostimulation (PBST) in reducing pain and anxiety during local anesthesia administration for pediatric dental extractions.
results_summary: TENS showed significantly lower pain scores and faster onset of local anesthesia compared to PBST, with improvements in physiological parameters like pulse rate and salivary pH. Both methods were effective alternatives to topical anesthesia, but TENS demonstrated superior efficacy in pain and anxiety reduction.
population_specificity: Children aged 12-16 years undergoing bilateral orthodontic extractions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of TENS in improving limb motor dysfunction in post-stroke patients through a systematic review of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found TENS statistically more effective than sham TENS in improving upper limb function, with a standardized mean difference of 3.58 (95% CI: 0.88, 6.27), based on FMA-UE, FIM, and CSS scores. However, variations in stimulation parameters limited the evidence for reliable clinical use.
population_specificity: Post-stroke patients with limb motor dysfunction (513 participants from 10 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antibacterial activity of a novel Fe3O4 nanocomposite coated with fenugreek seed gums and silver nanoparticles for potential water treatment applications.
results_summary: The Fe3O4/FSG/Ag nanocomposites demonstrated higher antibacterial activity against gram-negative and gram-positive bacteria compared to other samples and could be easily removed from water using a magnet.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on bacterial strains)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of fenugreek on reducing the severity of dysmenorrhea and its side effects in women with dysmenorrhea.
results_summary: Fenugreek reduced pain intensity in primary dysmenorrhea compared to placebo but showed no significant difference compared to mefenamic acid or Chandrasura churna. The evidence quality was low, and the true effect remains uncertain.
population_specificity: Women with dysmenorrhea

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the Bacillus subtilis ER-08 (BST) strain could enhance Fenugreek's growth and mitigate abiotic stresses like salinity and drought.
results_summary: The BST isolate demonstrated significant plant growth-promoting qualities, including hormone production and stress tolerance, while also suppressing Fusarium oxysporum growth. Fenugreek seed biopriming with BST improved developmental indices under greenhouse conditions.
population_specificity: Fenugreek plants under controlled greenhouse conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential protective effects of fenugreek saponin and nanofenugreek saponin against nicotine-induced toxicity in male rats.
results_summary: The study found that fenugreek saponin and nanofenugreek saponin significantly reduced DNA damage, improved liver tissue health, and increased antioxidant enzyme activity in nicotine-exposed rats. The compounds also enhanced the expression of liver-protective genes (GLAST and GLT-1).
population_specificity: Male rats exposed to nicotine.
effective_dosage: Fenugreek saponin (25, 50, and 100 mg/kg/day); nanofenugreek saponin (20, 40, and 80 mg/kg/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of fenugreek as a treatment for type 2 diabetes mellitus through a systematic review and meta-analysis of clinical trials.
results_summary: Fenugreek significantly improved glycemic control (FBG, 2-hPG, HbA1c) and lipid profiles (TC, TG, HDL-C) without severe adverse events, though mild gastrointestinal side effects were noted. No significant effects were observed on HOMA-IR, LDL-C, or BMI.
population_specificity: Individuals with type 2 diabetes mellitus (706 participants across 10 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to computationally assess fenugreek compounds' inhibitory activity on the androgen receptor (AR) to explore their potential anti-cancer effects in treating Benign Prostate Cancer (BPC).
results_summary: Molecular docking and dynamics simulations identified kaempferol and chlorogenic acid as promising AR antagonists, exhibiting stable binding and higher free binding energy than the reference ligand hydroxyflutamide. These compounds show potential as leads for BPC drug development.
population_specificity: In-silico study (no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of fenugreek seed ethanolic extract (FSEE) on bone cells, inflammation, hormones, and angiogenesis parameters in alveolar bone tissue following tooth extraction in an ovariectomized rat model.
results_summary: FSEE reduced blood estrogen levels, increased estrogen receptor-α expression, modified bone cell numbers, angiogenesis, VEGF, sclerostin, and the OPG/RANKL ratio, and altered inflammatory markers (IL-6, TGF-β1, and M1/M2 ratio). Inflammation was attenuated by reductions in IL-6 and sclerostin, and an increase in TGF-β1.
population_specificity: Adult female Wistar rats (ovariectomized model).
effective_dosage: 100 mg/kg BW, 200 mg/kg BW, and 400 mg/kg BW (intragastric route).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether fenugreek could protect neonatal rat cardiomyocytes against CoCl2-induced hypoxia and improve cellular functions like calcium signaling and beating rate.
results_summary: Fenugreek at 160 µg/ml for 24 hours protected cardiomyocytes from hypoxia-induced damage, reduced apoptotic markers (caspases -3, -6, -8, -9), improved calcium signaling and beating rate, and modulated gene expression (HIF-1α, Bcl-2, IP3R, ERK5, GLP-1r). CoCl2 alone increased hypoxia and apoptotic markers while decreasing Bcl-2 activity.
population_specificity: Neonatal rat cardiomyocytes (Sprague Dawley rats aged 0-2 days).
effective_dosage: 10-320 µg/ml, with 160 µg/ml being the effective concentration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-angiogenic and anti-proliferative effects of a hydro-alcoholic extract of fenugreek seed (HAEF) on human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs).
results_summary: HAEF reduced HUVEC viability with an IC50 of 200 μg/ml, decreased MMP-2/MMP-9, VEGF, and bFGF gene expression, and inhibited PI3K/Akt/cyclin D1 protein expression, suggesting potential anti-cancer properties.
population_specificity: Human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) in vitro.
effective_dosage: Various concentrations, with IC50 at 200 μg/ml.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential protective effects of fenugreek seeds extract against the toxic effects of anabolic steroids on cardiac and skeletal muscles in male albino rats.
results_summary: Fenugreek seeds extract showed a protective effect against biochemical and histopathological changes induced by anabolic steroids, improving antioxidant levels (SOD, Catalase, GSH) and reducing oxidative stress (MDA). It also mitigated degenerative changes and necrosis in cardiac and skeletal muscles.
population_specificity: Male albino rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review progress in using emerging technologies to extract bioactive compounds from Fenugreek and explore its applications in the food industry and therapeutic effects.
results_summary: The study found that Fenugreek has antimicrobial, antibacterial, hepatoprotective, anticancer, lactation-enhancing, and antidiabetic effects due to phytochemicals like galactomannans, saponins, alkaloids, and polyphenols. Emerging extraction technologies, particularly ultrasound and microwave, improved yield and biological activity of Fenugreek extracts.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review, no specific population studied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of ascaroside treatment in controlling Salmonella enterica on fenugreek sprouts to improve microbial safety.
results_summary: The study found that Salmonella populations were significantly higher on fenugreek sprouts compared to alfalfa, but treatment with ascaroside (1 mM or 1 µM) significantly reduced Salmonella levels by approximately 4 or 1 log CFU/g, respectively.
population_specificity: Commercial fenugreek seeds and sprouts inoculated with Salmonella enterica strains (S. Cubana and S. Stanley).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the physiological and molecular effects of zinc oxide nanoparticles (ZnO NPs) on fenugreek seedlings, focusing on biomass, biochemical parameters, and genetic variation.
results_summary: The study found that ZnO NPs at 30 mg/l improved biomass, bioactive compounds, and antioxidant activity in fenugreek seedlings, while higher concentrations (40-50 mg/l) induced oxidative stress. Genetic variation was limited across all ZnO NP treatments.
population_specificity: Fenugreek seedlings (Trigonella foenum-graecum).
effective_dosage: 10, 20, 30, 40, and 50 mg/l (single application via seed soaking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of intercropping fenugreek with Moldavian balm and the impact of different fertilization treatments (chemical, AMF, and AMF + NFB) on essential oil yield and composition.
results_summary: The study found that intercropping fenugreek with Moldavian balm, particularly in a 100:50 ratio, combined with AMF + NFB bio-fertilizer, improved essential oil yield and increased geranial content. The highest essential oil yield (15.28 kg ha-1) was observed in the Mb:F (4:2) intercropping pattern with AMF + NFB treatment.
population_specificity: Medicinal plant cultivation in East Azarbayhan, Iran (field study).
effective_dosage: Not specified (field study with intercropping ratios).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role and mechanism of vitamin C-elicited phytochemical-rich fenugreek sprout extract (IM6E) in managing diabetes through in vitro and in vivo studies.
results_summary: IM6E showed strong α-glucosidase inhibition and moderate α-amylase and invertase inhibition in vitro. In diabetic rats, IM6E improved antioxidant activity, normalized biochemical markers, reduced blood glucose, and increased insulin levels, with effects comparable to voglibose and insulin.
population_specificity: Normal and streptozotocin (STZ)-induced diabetic rats.
effective_dosage: 300 mg/kg body weight (best concentration), 100 mg/kg body weight (compared to insulin).
interactions: Synergistic effects with voglibose noted, but no other interactions mentioned.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of fenugreek oil on parasitological, immunological, and biochemical parameters in mice infected with Schistosoma mansoni.
results_summary: Fenugreek oil significantly reduced the number of S. mansoni worms and egg counts, improved antioxidant levels, and showed anti-inflammatory and anti-apoptotic effects, comparable to praziquantel in some aspects.
population_specificity: Mice infected with Schistosoma mansoni

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of Furocyst®, a standardized Fenugreek extract, in managing PCOS symptoms and reversing reproductive and endocrine damage.
results_summary: Furocyst® reduced ovarian cyst sizes by >40%, improved LH:FSH ratios, lowered testosterone and prolactin levels, and regularized menstrual cycles. It also alleviated insulin resistance, dyslipidemia, and improved liver function.
population_specificity: 107 female volunteers aged 18-45 years with PCOS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate fenugreek seed mucilage (FGG) as a natural flocculant for arsenic removal in water treatment, comparing its efficacy to flaxseed mucilage (FSG) and commercial xanthan gum (XG).
results_summary: Fenugreek seed mucilage (FGG) achieved 92.3% removal of organic arsenate (S1) and 69.6% removal of inorganic arsenate (S2), demonstrating good efficiency comparable to commercial xanthan gum. The study highlighted FGG as a sustainable alternative for arsenic removal in water treatment.
population_specificity: Water treatment systems (not human subjects).
study_duration: Not specified (kinetic study focused on process optimization).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of fenugreek seed supplementation on goat performance, milk fatty acid profile, and milk volatile compounds during mid-lactation.
results_summary: Fenugreek supplementation increased milk fat concentration, reduced serum cholesterol and triglycerides, enhanced unsaturated fatty acids, and elevated specific volatile compounds (e.g., 2-propanone) in milk, without affecting feed intake, weight gain, or milk yield.
population_specificity: 20 mid-lactation Turkish Saanen dairy goats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Blue Fenugreek Kale Extract (BFKE) on skin aging, focusing on protein oxidation, skin barrier function, and hydration.
results_summary: BFKE significantly reduced protein carbonylation in human dermal fibroblasts stressed with urban pollution and improved skin barrier function and hydration in a clinical study, though no significant changes were observed in wrinkle severity, skin sagging, elasticity, or inflammatory and oxidative stress biomarkers.
population_specificity: 59 volunteers in a clinical study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antifatigue effects of fenugreek extract (FE) on mitophagy and its underlying mechanisms in an exhaustive exercise-induced fatigue rat model.
results_summary: FE improved antioxidant enzyme activities, reduced oxidative stress markers, enhanced mitochondrial function, and regulated mitophagy-related protein expression, demonstrating antifatigue effects via the FUNDC1/LC3B signaling pathway.
population_specificity: Exhaustive exercise-induced fatigue rat model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of fenugreek seed extract on memory, depression, quality of life, blood pressure, and oxidative stress markers in adults with mild-to-moderate Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in memory, quality of life, and oxidative stress markers (increased TAC, reduced MDA), as well as reductions in depression and blood pressure levels after fenugreek supplementation.
population_specificity: 82 adults with mild-to-moderate Alzheimer's disease in geriatric homes in Iran.
effective_dosage: 5 cc of fenugreek seed extract daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential anticancer activity of processed and unprocessed fenugreek seeds and leaves, focusing on their apoptotic-inducing properties and effects on inflammatory gene regulation in cancerous cell lines.
results_summary: The study found that air-dried fenugreek leaves and unprocessed/germinated fenugreek seeds exhibited significant anti-proliferative and apoptotic effects against HepG2, HCT-116, and MCF-7 cancer cell lines, with notable up-regulation of pro-apoptotic genes (p53, caspase-3, Bax) and down-regulation of anti-apoptotic genes (Bcl-2). Household processing methods enhanced these effects.
population_specificity: Cancerous cell lines (HepG2, HCT-116, MCF-7, VERO).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how melatonin protects fenugreek against the negative effects of salt stress and enhances its biochemical and physiological responses.
results_summary: Melatonin application prevented chlorophyll degradation, increased antioxidant biosynthesis, maintained ionic homeostasis, and boosted diosgenin content under salinity stress, with a 5.5-fold increase in diosgenin concentration at 60 ppm melatonin and 150 mM salinity.
population_specificity: Fenugreek plants under salinity stress.
effective_dosage: 30, 60, and 90 ppm melatonin; 150 mM and 300 mM salinity stress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Fenugreek seed galactomannan (F-GAL) and aqueous extract (FS-AE) to prevent liver and kidney damage in streptozotocin-induced type 1 diabetic rats.
results_summary: Both F-GAL and FS-AE reduced fasting hyperglycemia, improved lipid profiles, attenuated pancreatic and organ damage, and reduced oxidative stress and inflammation markers in diabetic rats. The treatments also enhanced antioxidant activity and Nrf2 signaling.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced type 1 diabetic rats and non-diabetic controls.
effective_dosage: 500 mg/kg each of F-GAL and FS-AE.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Aspergillus niger-mediated release of PO43- from fish bone products could reduce phytoavailable Pb in Pb-polluted soil and minimize Pb uptake in fenugreek.
results_summary: The APII-C + A. niger treatment significantly reduced Pb phytoavailability in soil and Pb uptake in fenugreek shoots, roots, and grain, with grain Pb levels remaining within WHO/FAO safety limits. The treatment also improved soil quality and fenugreek nutritional and physiological parameters.
population_specificity: Fenugreek plants grown in Pb-polluted soil.
effective_dosage: Not specified (APII powder, APII char, and A. niger inoculum doses not detailed).
study_duration: Not specified (pot study duration not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of co-supplementation of berberine and fenugreek on cardio-metabolic status and quality of life in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: The study found that the combination of berberine and fenugreek significantly reduced fasting insulin, HbA1C, and hs-CRP levels, improved insulin resistance, fasting blood sugar, and quality of life scores compared to placebo.
population_specificity: 50 patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
effective_dosage: 200 mg fenugreek seed powder per day (combined with 300 mg berberine in 3 capsules/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the effects of Fenugreek seed extract (FSE) on broiler immunity and determine the optimal dosage for broiler production.
results_summary: FSE improved average daily gain, reduced feed-to-gain ratio, lowered serum cholesterol, and enhanced immune markers (immunoglobulins, interleukins, and interferon-γ) in broilers. The recommended FSE dosage was 100 mg/kg in the diet.
population_specificity: 1-day-old yellow feather broilers (420 birds total).
effective_dosage: 50, 100, 200, 400, and 800 mg/kg FSE in the basal diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of fenugreek alone versus fenugreek combined with honey on breastfeeding success in lactating mothers.
results_summary: The study found that fenugreek alone did not significantly improve breastfeeding success, but the combination of fenugreek and honey significantly increased breastfeeding success scores. No significant differences in complications were observed between the two groups.
population_specificity: 75 breastfeeding mothers with infants aged 1-5 months, practicing exclusive breastfeeding, referred to a health center in Tehran, Iran.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the main flavonoids in fenugreek leaves and evaluate their antioxidant activity, specifically their protective effects against H₂O₂-induced oxidative damage in L02 hepatocytes.
results_summary: FLFs contained eight flavonoids, primarily quercetin and kaempferol, and demonstrated dose-dependent protection against oxidative stress by enhancing antioxidant enzyme activity (SOD, CAT, GSH), reducing LDH release and MDA content, and modulating the MAPKs/Nrf2/HO-1 signaling pathway to inhibit apoptosis.
population_specificity: L02 hepatocytes (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of fenugreek saponin (FS) and nanofenugreek saponin (NFS) against nicotine-induced toxicity in male rats.
results_summary: FS and NFS significantly reduced nicotine-induced micronuclei formation, sperm abnormalities, AChE gene expression, and histological damage in rat testis, suggesting protective effects against nicotine toxicity.
population_specificity: Male rats
effective_dosage: FS (25, 50, and 100 mg/kg/day); NFS (20, 40, and 80 mg/kg/day)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of carboxymethyl fenugreek gum (CMFG) gel loaded with itraconazole nanovesicles (ITZ-nPEVs) for enhancing transungual drug absorption and antifungal efficacy against Candida albicans.
results_summary: The ITZ-nPEVs showed high drug content and entrapment efficiency, improved nail hydration, and significantly greater antifungal activity compared to a commercial gel. The CMFG-ITZ-nPEVs gel demonstrated superior drug uptake and inhibition zones against Candida albicans.
population_specificity: Onychomycotic patients (implied for clinical investigation, though the abstract primarily discusses in vitro and ex vivo results).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anticholesterolemic efficacy of fenugreek extract, both alone and in a blend, compared to red yeast extract (RYR) in an in vitro hepatic cell line model.
results_summary: Fenugreek demonstrated anticholesterolemic activity by reducing total and free cholesterol and influencing bile acids biosynthesis. The blend (ACFB) showed similar efficacy to RYR but with lower required concentrations, suggesting potential additive effects.
population_specificity: In vitro study using HepG2 hepatic cell line.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the hepatoprotective effects of Fenugreek seeds' extract in thioacetamide-induced liver damage in rats.
results_summary: Fenugreek seeds' extract restored altered liver markers (total bilirubin, direct bilirubin, ALT, ALP) and antioxidant enzyme activities (catalase, SOD) in rats with thioacetamide-induced liver damage, confirming its hepatoprotective role.
population_specificity: Male Sprague Dawley rats (200-264g)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anticancer activity of germinated fenugreek seed extract against pancreatic cancer in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: The germinated fenugreek seed extract increased survival rates in pancreatic cancer mice and protected pancreatic tissue from cancer-related lesions. The study demonstrated efficacy in both in vitro and in vivo models.
population_specificity: Albino mice injected with BXPC-3 pancreatic cancer cell lines.
effective_dosage: IC50 of the fenugreek extract (specific dosage not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-cancer potential of methanolic fenugreek seed extract (FSE) and its molecular mechanism of action in breast cancer cells.
results_summary: FSE exhibited dose-dependent cytotoxicity in breast cancer cells, inducing apoptosis through mitochondrial depolarization, ROS increase, and p53-mediated mitotic catastrophe. In vivo acute toxicity tests showed no toxic effects in mice.
population_specificity: MCF-7 and SK-BR3 breast cancer cells (in vitro) and mice (in vivo).
effective_dosage: IC50 doses of 150 μg/mL (MCF-7) and 40 μg/mL (SK-BR3).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the hepatoprotective effects of fenugreek seed extract on thioacetamide-induced liver damage in rats, specifically assessing its impact on glucose and lipid profiles.
results_summary: Fenugreek seed extract significantly improved plasma glucose and HDL levels while reducing triglycerides, cholesterol, LDL, VLDL, and total lipids in rats with liver damage, demonstrating hypoglycemic and hypolipidemic effects.
population_specificity: Male Sprague Dawley rats with thioacetamide-induced liver damage.
effective_dosage: 2ml of 2% Fenugreek seed extract orally daily.
study_duration: 4 weeks (from the 4th to the 8th week of the study).
